titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the South Africa Now Collection

did.unittitle: South Africa Now collection

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The collection consists of videotapes and a small number of transcripts, log books, and publicity files relating to the television program South Africa Now , produced by Globalvision from 1988 to 1991. It includes a nearly complete run of tapes of the approximately 150 newscasts produced during the three year run of the program as well as approximately 2000 tapes of interviews, short reports, documentaries, stock footage, and other footage used in the program's production. The show documents various aspects of South African politics, government, and culture during the final years of apartheid.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: The entire collection, with the exception of the paper files in boxes 2384-2391, is available in digital form through Manuscripts and Archives.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
The entire collection, with the exception of the paper files in boxes 2384-2391, is digitized. Researchers must use the digital copies instead of the originals.

Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy for their personal use should consult Copying Services information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright to materials in Series I and Series XVIII has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: South Africa Now Collection (MS 1818). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The television news program South Africa Now first aired in April 1988. The program actively sought to fill a perceived void in news coverage of South Africa and the anti-apartheid movement in particular, stemming from media censorship measures instituted by the South African government in 1986. Produced by Globalvision, Inc., a television production company founded in 1987 by Rory O'Connor and Danny Schechter to focus on global human rights issues, South Africa Now ran weekly on public television stations throughout the United States and in fifteen other countries. Segments of the program occasionally received even wider distribution when they were aired on the CNN's Weekly World Report .

The program covered South African news, produced background and investigative reports on the affairs of South Africa and neighboring states, and provided cultural features documenting South African theater, musicians, writers, and artists. In the three years it ran, the program covered a highly turbulent era in South African history that saw severe repression of black and colored South Africans, the release of Nelson Mandela from prison, and the end of the apartheid system. Because its reporters and producers were not welcome in South Africa, the show relied primarily on material culled from the South African news, European sources, and footage shot by independent producers in South Africa and smuggled out of the country. Regular anchors, reporters, and other contributors included Carolyn Craven, Fana Kakana, Thandeka Gqubule, Mweli Mzizi, Phillip Tomlinson, Joseph Diescho, and Eric Nadler.

Globalvision ceased production of South Africa Now in April 1991, due to lack of operating funds. Shortly before the last show aired, Globalvision, Inc. received a George Polk Award for Journalistic Excellence in recognition of South Africa Now .

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in eighteen series: I. Episodes, 1988-1991; II. Short Reports, circa 1985-1991; III. Documentaries, 1980-1991; IV. Stock Footage, circa 1987-1990; V. Interviews, circa 1978-1991; VI. Cultural Tapes, circa 1979-1991; VII. American Protest, 1986-1991; VIII. Other Network Footage, 1985-1991; IX. Jesse Jackson Diaries, 1986; X. United Nations TV, 1988-1989; XI. Stills, circa 1988-1990; XII. Miscellaneous PAL Tapes, 1984-1990; XIII. Mandela in America, 1990; XIV. South African Tourism Board, 1983-1988, undated; XV. Footage from Independent Producers from South Africa, 1984-1989; XVI. South African Footage, 1989-1990; XVII. Reports about South Africa Now, circa 1988-1991; XVIII. Miscellaneous Unnumbered Tapes, 1987-circa 1990; XIX. Paper Logs and Publicity Files, circa 1988-1994.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Due to a numbering anomaly and the separation of an unplayable tape from the collection, there is no box 605 or 2370 in the collection.

odd.head: General
odd.p: This collection was digitized through the generous support of the Arcadia Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of videotapes and a small number of transcripts, log books, and publicity files relating to the television program South Africa Now , produced by Globalvision from 1988 to 1991. It includes a nearly complete run of tapes of the approximately 150 newscasts produced during the three year run of the program as well as approximately 2000 tapes of interviews, short reports, documentaries, stock footage, and other footage used in the program's production.

The collection includes visual documentation of the final years of apartheid in South Africa and includes interviews with and other significant footage of anti-apartheid leaders, including Nelson Mandela, Winnie Mandela, Desmond Tutu, Walter Sisulu, Albertina Sisulu, Albie Sachs, Joe Slovo, Thabo Mbeki, Allan Boesak, Oliver Tambo, Beyers Naude, and many others. It also documents the activities of the South African government and its leaders, particularly P.W. Botha and F. W. De Klerk. Many organizations also receive extensive coverage, such as the African National Congress (ANC), the Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU), and the South-West African Peoples Organization (SWAPO). Many editions of the program included the segment "Frontline Focus," which reported the news in the southern African states of Angola, Namibia, Zambia, Zimbabwe, and Mozambique. South Africa Now produced at least one cultural segment per show. The collection, therefore, contains footage of South African artists, playwrights, musicians, authors, and filmmakers, including Athol Fugard, Hugh Masakela, Ladysmith Black Mambazo, Mzwakhe Mbuli, Johnny Klegg, Gcina Mhlopher, Peter Magubane, and Nadine Gordimer. Finally, the collection documents the activities of the international anti-apartheid movement that put political and economic pressure on South Africa to end the system of apartheid.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Box 2370, Tape T1, McNeil/Lehrer NewsHour report on South Africa Now , 1988 Oct 26, was unplayable and removed from the collection.

did.unittitle: Episodes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series conatins full episodes of South Africa Now , arranged by season. Transcripts are filed at the end of the series.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials in this series are digitized. Researchers must use the digital copies instead of the originals.

did.unittitle: First Season
Episode 1

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: popular education in South African townships; campaign to release children from prison for Christmas; South African government music video, done in response to "Sun City" and "We Are the World," an interracial propaganda ploy that failed.

did.unittitle: Episode 2

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: "Black on Black Violence," a look at Pretoria's use of vigilante squads in stirring up violence in the townships; how the South African government wants the world to see it, with excerpts from an official tourism film, Love Changes People and People Change Things .

did.unittitle: Episode 3

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: torture of children in detention with preview of an English documentary featuring testimony of children released from prison and conflict footage never seen before on United States television; video report on the funeral of the slain France African National Congress (ANC) representative, Dulcie September, in Paris; report on death of writer Alan Paton; excerpts from the visit of the cast of the hit Broadway show, Sarafina , to the United Nations; a look at the vote on sanctions; Pretoria's stance, with more highlights from a South African government-financed film.
Extraneous, non-episode footage included at end of the tape.

did.unittitle: Episode 4

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: the "Press Ban," a report from Afravision inside South Africa on how black journalists cover the news in the townships; South Africa Now interview with a visiting township reporter; analysis of the background to killings of ANC officials from Jennifer Davis of the American Committee on Africa and William Johnston of Episcopal Churchpeople for a Free Southern Africa; Pretoria's position, with excerpts of a widely distributed anti-ANC film, A Time for Candor , with commentary by Jennifer Davis.

did.unittitle: Episode 5

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: sanctions and reform, conflicting views on the sanctions debate and analysis of the government's "reform" program with Mark Swelling, a Johannesburg-based political analyst and contributor to The Weekly Mail and Bobby Godsell, labor negotiator for the Anglo-American Corporation; report from inside South Africa on a diverse range of views from black South Africans on sanctions.

did.unittitle: Episode 6

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: Bishop Tutu in America and highlights from his sermon at New York's Riverside Church, with excerpts from a major press conference; report from inside South Africa on the growing conflict between the church and the state; Bishop Tutu singing freedom songs.

did.unittitle: Episode 7

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: Namibia, interview with Sam Nujoma, President of the South West African People's Organization (SWAPO), with highlights from an English documentary for background, and further analysis, in an interview with Damu Smith, director of the Washington Office on Africa, of the implications of the Angola-South Africa negotiations; Miriam Mekeba's comeback with statements and music from "Mama Africa," South Africa's leading singer.

did.unittitle: Episode 8

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: the war in Mozambique with eyewitness testimony by two doctors who have worked in Mozambique for many years; background reports from two films: Alliance in Action , produced by UNICEF and narrated by Harry Belafonte, and Frontline South Africa: Destructive Engagement ; interview with Mary De Almeida of Children's Fund for Southern Africa (CHISA); the A.F.R.I.C.A. video in which rappers support the front-line state, with report on the video's origins by Jesse Jackson.

did.unittitle: Episode 9

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: whites against apartheid, with interviews with Dennis Goldberg, leader of the African National Congress on trial with Nelson Mandela in 1963 and imprisoned for twenty-two years, and Nina Overton, a prominent Afrikaner academic; activities of the UDF and Black Sash in reaching out to whites; excerpt from a documentary on Beyers Naudé, an Afrikaner minister who became an anti-apartheid activist; Johnny Clegg and Savuka, a "rockumentary" on South Africa's best known multi-racial band.

did.unittitle: Episode 10

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: political bannings and new press restrictions inside South Africa; a three-day labor stay-away in June that brought the country to a virtual standstill; the American censorship of the Nelson Mandela concert in London, with an interview with Little Steven who explains the "cleansing" of political message in the Mandela concert by American television; report on political repression in South Africa, with interviews with Miriam Jacobs of Human Rights Watch and Eric Goldstein of The Committee to Protect Journalists; the Freedom Beat Fest in Central Park.

did.unittitle: Episode 11

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: the war in Angola with an exclusive interview with United States- and South Africa-backed Unia?o Nacional para a Independe?ncia Total de Angola (UNITA) leader, Jonas Savimbi, and interviews with American black activists Benjamin Chavis and Elombe Brathe; report on the Angolan-South African conflict with recent footage from the frontline by independent television journalist, Jon Alpert; Senegal's top musician, Youssou N'Dour, singing for South Africa,

did.unittitle: Duplicating master
Episode 12

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: Nelson Mandela turns seventy in prison; American premiere of a new film, Remembering Mandela , by Peter Davis; a report on the negotiations between Angola, South Africa, Cuba. and the United States to end the war in Angola, with an interview with Phillip van Niekirk, South African correspondent for The Boston Globe ; a report on Zwelakhe Sisulu, editor of The New Nation , who was recently transferred from prison to a Johannesburg hospital; interview with Tony Weaver, South African journalist, on the new press restrictions in South Africa; premiere of new short video pieces in tribute to Nelson Mandela from the Institute for Contemporary Art in London; Special AKA sings for the release of Nelson Mandela.

did.unittitle: Episode 13

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: worldwide commemorations of Nelson Mandela's seventieth birthday; exclusive footage of Winnie Mandela's press conference in Johannesburg; interview with Paul David, leader of South Africa's Indian Congress, on the unlikely release of Nelson Mandela; footage of the New York birthday celebration in Central Park; excerpt from the Reverend Jesse Jackson's speech at the Democratic National Convention on the party's unified stance on South Africa: analysis by Africa Report contributing editor Michael Maren on the Angolan negotiations; South Africa's defense force under threat, both on the Angolan battlefield and at home, including an interview with Heinz Klug, an exiled South African journalist who speaks on White South African's "End Conscription" campaign; Sakhile, one of South Africa's most popular jazz bands, plays at the Rainbow Club outside of Durban in honor of Nelson Mandela.

did.unittitle: Duplicating master
Episode N708

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: SAN receives prestigious Polk Award; legislation introduced to do away with segregation in land ownership; violence continues during peace rallies nationwide; key witness in Winnie Mandela affair admits he lied during cross examination; hanging deemed for political prisoners; Spike Lee and others lobby Congress to keep pressure on economic sanctions; Namibia celebrates first year of independence; a look at Namibia's future politically and socially.

did.unittitle: Duplicating master
Episode N709

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: music special on artists from Southern Africa: songs reflecting political turmoil: Brenda Fassie's Black President music video; Johnny Clegg video, Papa Stop the War ; Sipho "Hotstix" Mabuse video; urban and rural sounds: Ladysmith Black Mambazo video, Hello My Baby ; The Mahotella Oueens's Kazet , Urban Africa ; Mahlathini, "The Lion of Soweto," sings, "This is our kind of prison in Africa…"; touring Mozambique, Zimbabwe, & Namibia: Thomas Mapfumo & The Blacks Unlimited, Ngoma Yekweda ; video clip of Namibian singer, composer Nathan Ndjiharine; African rhythms and jazz: video clip of Hugh Masekela's, Grazing in the Grass ; Jonas Gwangwa video, Amandla , The ANC cultural group; Abdullah Lloraham sings, They'll Come A Time ; anti-apartheid whites & Capetown rappers: Andre LeToit sings Yes, Life Is Ponderous ...; Gereformeerde Blues Band singing, I flip channels to TV3 ...; The Genuines, Die Struggle ; Kalahari Surfers, Running Out of Time ; Prophets of Da City, Our World ; video clip of Miriam Makeba's, Amampondo .

did.unittitle: Duplicating master
Episode N710

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: Nelson Mandela and Chief Buthelezi meet on March 29 to discuss ways to end the violence in South Africa, which took the lives of 2677 in 1990, the most recent attack by police killed eleven and wounded twenty-nine mourners in Davidson; ANC member Billing Amodela was gunned down in Zambia; the future of sanctions is discussed along with a look at what the lifting of them in the face of recent reforms is doing; Winnie Mandela's court case takes a number of new turns, among them allegations of police torture of Mrs. Mandela's co-defendant and the suggestion that Mrs. Mandela's motive was to protect boys being sexually abused by a white minister; war escalates in Mozambique and Namibia demands return of its only deepwater bay by South Africa; SAAMSTAN in Namibia organizes to provide housing for the many homeless there; an exploration of the recent refusal by PBS to air Globalvision's documentary, Mandela in America, an excerpt of that documentary chronicling Mandela's visit to Detroit is featured; the influential African Artists Fund works to find training and education for South African artists.

did.unittitle: Duplicating master
Episode N711

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: South Africa Now Best of Show: a look back at the history of South Africa Now and highlights of some of the best shows; quotes from Jimmy Carter, Jesse Jackson, Oprah Winfrey, F. W. De Klerk, Linda Ellerbee, Nelson Mandela and others; weekly background reports done to support and enrich stories.

did.unittitle: Duplicating master
Episode N712

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: South Africa Now : Best of Show: Part II: more "best of" highlights plus a look at the issues still facing Southern Africa as South Africa Now prepares to go off the air; overview of the story of the "Frontline States," the countries adjoining South Africa which have been the targets of colonial rule, war and destabilization; a review of the segments on South African cultural expression and artistic creativity of Southern African writers, poets, musicians and theater people.

did.unittitle: Duplicating master
Episode N713

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The episode includes: "The New South Africa Now" final show: footage of George Polk award ceremony, South Africa Now is honored with one of the most prestigious awards in broadcast journalism; announcement that South Africa Now may be independently produced by a team of Southern African media organizations, followed by comments on Southern African broadcasting; broadcasting service needs to remain independent from control by any political party; black townships remain a battleground, violent clashes between Inkatha and ANC supporters; discussion of controversy over land reform and the Land Act; independent filmmaker, William Kentridge, demonstrates his innovative animated film technique with a short film about a man who gets transformed into a monument.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes a variety of tapes compiled during the production of South Africa Now . Many of the tapes include news segments taken from other programs on numerous topics related to the anti-apartheid movement and other South African matters. It is arranged sequentially by a tape numbering system used by Globalvision and tape titles used by Globalvision have been preserved.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials in this series are digitized. Researchers must use the digital copies instead of the originals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes videotapes of documentaries on a wide range of topics relating to South African society, history, and culture. The tapes were presumably compiled and used by Globalvision as source and background materials for the production of South Africa Now . It is arranged sequentially by a tape numbering system used by Globalvision and tape titles used by Globalvision have been preserved.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials in this series are digitized. Researchers must use the digital copies instead of the originals.

Interviews

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes raw footage of interviews conducted in the process of producing South Africa Now . Interview subjects include various South African political and cultural figures including Nelson Mandela, Desmond Tutu, Thabo Mbeki, Albie Sachs, Athol Fugard, Hugh Masekela, and many others. There are also interviews with Americans and others interested in South African affairs and the anti-apartheid movement, including Jesse Jackson and David Dinkins. It is arranged sequentially by a tape numbering system used by Globalvision and tape titles used by Globalvision have been preserved. Listed at the end of the series, there are four boxes of logbooks that provide greater details about the interviews.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials in this series are digitized. Researchers must use the digital copies instead of the originals.

Cultural Tapes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes tapes with raw footage from the cultural segments of South Africa Now . It is arranged sequentially by a tape numbering system used by Globalvision and tape titles used by Globalvision have been preserved.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials in this series are digitized. Researchers must use the digital copies instead of the originals.

Mandela in America

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists of footage taken for the documentary Mandela in America , a film that documents Nelson Mandela's visit to the United States in 1990, after his release from prison. The footage includes both public and private moments from Mandela's speaking tour. It is arranged sequentially by a tape numbering system used by Globalvision and tape titles used by Globalvision have been preserved.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials in this series are digitized. Researchers must use the digital copies instead of the originals.
